com.soa.message

Class AbstractMessage

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.soa.message.AbstractMessage
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Message
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SimpleMessage

    public abstract class AbstractMessage
extends java.lang.Object
implements Message
    Abstract implementation of Message interface that can be easily extended for specific implementations.
    Since:
    5.0.

    • Constructor Summary

        public javax.xml.transform.Source getContent()
                                      throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns the content of the message. WARNING: Do not make changes directly to the returned Source object without calling Message.setContent(Source).
        Specified by:
        getContent in interface Message
        Returns:
        Source holding the message content.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to retrieve message content. Possibly caused by badly formed content.

      • setContent

        public void setContent(javax.xml.transform.Source content)
                throws com.digev.fw.exception.GException
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Changes the message content. If normalized either use this method for setting content or Message.addPart(String,Object) if multiple parts are needed. Do not use both methods.
        Specified by:
        setContent in interface Message
        Parameters:
        content - Source holding the message content.
        Throws:
        com.digev.fw.exception.GException - Thrown if unable to change the content. Possibly caused by passing in badly formed content.

      • getPropertyNames

        public java.util.Set getPropertyNames()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns the names of the properties associated with the message. Changes made to the Set are reflected in the message, so if a name is removed from the Set, the property is removed from the message. Names cannot be added however.
        Specified by:
        getPropertyNames in interface Message
        Returns:
        Set of String property names.

      • getID

        public java.lang.String getID()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns the ID of the message (if any). An ID is typically used when the message is part of an asynchronous exchange. It may not be available for synchronous exchanges. If present, the ID will be unique between the producer and consumer of the messsage while the exchange it is part of is active.
        Specified by:
        getID in interface Message
        Returns:
        String identifier of the message, null if none available.

      • setID

        public void setID(java.lang.String id)
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Changes the ID of the message. The ID will be unique between the producer and consumer of the messsage while the exchange it is part of is active.
        Specified by:
        setID in interface Message
        Parameters:
        id - String identifier of the message.

      • getCorrelationID

        public java.lang.String getCorrelationID()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns a correlation identifier (if any) that can be used to correlate this message with another. The most common example is for correlating an asynchronous response to a request message. This would be done by using the request message's ID as the response message's correlation ID.
        Specified by:
        getCorrelationID in interface Message
        Returns:
        String correlation identifier, null if none available.

      • setCorrelationID

        public void setCorrelationID(java.lang.String id)
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Changes the correlation ID of the message. The most common use is for asynchronous messaging. The request message ID would be set as the response message's correlation ID.
        Specified by:
        setCorrelationID in interface Message
        Parameters:
        id - String correlation identifier.

      • setSecuritySubject

        public void setSecuritySubject(javax.security.auth.Subject subject)
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Changes the security subject for the message with the consumer subject category (urn:org:federatedgovernance:security:subject-category:consumer). The security subject identifies the entity sending the message. This is a convenience method as a Map of all subjects associated with the message can be accessed through the MessageProperties.SECURITY_SUBJECTS property.
        Specified by:
        setSecuritySubject in interface Message
        Parameters:
        subject - Subject identifying the application sending the message.

The security subject identifies the entity sending the message. This is a convenience method as a Map of all subjects associated with the message can be accessed through the MessageProperties.SECURITY_SUBJECTS property.
        Specified by:
        getSecuritySubject in interface Message
        Returns:
        Subject identifying the application sending the message.

      • canCarryBindingHeaders

        public boolean canCarryBindingHeaders()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns if the message can carry binding headers. Some types of messages are sent using protocols that don't support binding headers. Indicating that can save processing time during mediation.
        Specified by:
        canCarryBindingHeaders in interface Message
        Returns:
        true if binding headers may be use, false if not.

      • addPart

        public void addPart(java.lang.String name,
                    java.lang.Object part)
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Normalized messages can support multiple parts. A part is synonymous with a message part as defined in the WSDL 1.1 spec, it is a named piece of content. The parts of a normalized message can then be encoded in a protocol specific way by a binding, i.e., query parameters, path parameteters, headers, or RPC encoded XML elements. If the message is not normalized there will be no parts. Use Message.getContent() to get the content of the message. If the message is normalized there may be content accessed using Message.getContent() instead of parts.
        Specified by:
        addPart in interface Message
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the part, should correspond to a WSDL definend message part.
        part - Value/content of the part. Typically a part should be an XML element that corresponds to what is defined in the WSDL definition. A part could be something other than that but unless the consumer of the message can read the content it will fail.

      • getPart

        public java.lang.Object getPart(java.lang.String name)
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns the value/content of the part with the given name.
        Specified by:
        getPart in interface Message
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the part.
        Returns:
        Value/content of the part.

        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns the names of the parts in the message (if any).
        Specified by:
        getPartNames in interface Message
        Returns:
        Set of part names. The set is mutable so changes to the set will be reflected in the message.

      • arePartsEmpty

        public boolean arePartsEmpty()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns whether there are any parts or not (empty) in the message. If there are no parts there is likely content returned in Message.getContent().
        Specified by:
        arePartsEmpty in interface Message
        Returns:
        true if no parts in message, false if there are.

      • getParts

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getParts()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        Returns a map of parts keyed by their name.
        Specified by:
        getParts in interface Message
        Returns:
        Map of parts keyed by their name. The map is muutable so any changes will be reflected in the message. If there are no parts defined null will be returned.

      • setContentPartName

        public void setContentPartName(java.lang.String name)
        Description copied from interface: Message
        When using parts in a message one of those parts can be considered the content of the message (see Message.getContent()). This method can be used to specify the name of the part that should be considered the message content.
        Specified by:
        setContentPartName in interface Message
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the part holding the message content.

      • getContentPartName

        public java.lang.String getContentPartName()
        Description copied from interface: Message
        When using parts in a message one of those parts can be considered the content of the message (see Message.getContent()). This method will return the name of the part that holds the content.
        Specified by:
        getContentPartName in interface Message
        Returns:
        Part name holding the message content.
